ALLEGATION:
Female residents snuck into each other's bedroom for a "sleepover."
INVESTIGATION:
On January 13, 2020, I received and reviewed Children's Village's policies regarding
supervision. The following procedures are listed under the general duties and
responsibilities:
 The afternoon staff will begin key ins at 9:30 p.m. and continue every 15 minutes
through 11:00 p.m.
2

 At the beginning of the midnight shift (11:00 p.m.), midnight staff are to account
for all residents in their care by visually checking all residents and confirming
visual checks with the bed chart.
 Bed checks and key ins will be completed every 15 minutes beginning at 11:15
p.m. and concluding at 7:00 a.m. The 11:15 p.m. bed check will be reported to
control with a phone call. Key ins will begin at 11:30 p.m. Keying in confirms staff
have physically (visually) checked on the presence and safety of each resident
and the dorm/room has been checked. Visual inspection includes seeing skin,
arms, legs or head protruding from under the blanket.
 Fifteen-minute key ins will have a five-minute variance.
 Staff must investigate further if there is any suspicion that residents are not safe
or missing.
 Report any unusual resident activity (restless ness, illness, crying, etc.) to
supervisor immediately; document the activity in residents log and complete an
incident report, if necessary.
 Minimum of one log entry per shift per staff member’s assigned cottage.
 Bed charts and daily logs are to be updated and accurate. This procedure should
be repeated during rotations.
 Flashlights are available in all units. Staff are to have a flashlight accessible to
them at all times.
 Prep radios are to be with staff at all times.
 Viewing of television is prohibited as well as electronic devices (i.e. i-pad, video
games, cell phones, lap top computers, etc.) and any other devices considered
by supervisory staff to be a distraction.
 Headphones and ear buds are prohibited.
The following procedures are listed under Mandy’s Place:
 Staff must sit in the main lobby area and be positioned so they have a view of all
dorm doors.
 All dorm doors must remain open at all times.
 All special precautions must be followed and documented at all times (i.e. CO,
SP, MCO, ER).
 Staff will assist new admittances. Duties include showering resident, completing
body sheets, preparing rooms, providing food, checking for contraband and
performing clothing searches.
I interviewed Resident 1 face-to-face at the facility on January 21, 2020. She stated that
on the night of January 7, 2020, Resident 3 asked her to sneak into Resident 3’s room
because it was her birthday and she was going to be leaving soon. She stated that they
wanted to have a slumber party. Resident 1 stated that Resident 2 was already in
Resident 3’s room when she went into the room. She reported that she does not
remember what time she went into the room. Resident 1 stated that throughout the
night staff completed room checks. She reported that staff turned on the lights and
talked to Resident 3 when they checked the room. Resident 1 stated that when staff
looked in the room she was hiding under the bed and Resident 2 was hiding in the
corner. She reported that she had to go to the bathroom, so she put a blanket over her
3

head to try and hide who she was. When she went to the bathroom, she stated that a
staff person asked her what room she came out of. She could not recall which staff
person questioned her whereabouts. Resident 1 stated that she then went back to her
room and went to sleep. She reported that she does not know how long she was in
Resident 3’s room.
I interviewed Children’s Village Staff Person A face-to-face at the facility on January 21,
2020. He stated that the residents must be in their rooms between 8:30 p.m. - 9:00
p.m. and lights have to be turned off at 9:30 p.m. Staff Person A stated that on the night
of January 7, 2020 the three girls were a little silly, but there was nothing suspicious that
he recalled had occurred. He reported that he did not see the residents go into
Resident 3’s room. Staff Person A stated that he completed room checks prior to his
shift ending at 9:30 p.m. He stated that when he completes room checks, he does not
typically go into the room. He reported that he peeks his head in the room and closes
the door. Staff Person A stated that depending on the emotional state of the resident,
the resident’s door may be closed at night.
I interviewed Children's Village Staff Person B face-to-face at the facility on January 21,
2020. Staff Person B reported that she works 3:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. She stated that
she did not know Resident 1 and Resident 2 were in Resident’s 3 room. Staff Person B
reported that Staff Person A and Children’s Village Staff Person C were located in the
hallway during the night shift. She was focused on another resident, who was being
disruptive at bedtime. Staff Person B reported that the residents must be in their rooms
at 8:30 p.m. and lights have to be turned out at 9:00 p.m. She stated that Staff Person
A completed room checks for the hallway in which the residents’ rooms are located.
She could not recall if she had completed room checks that night. Staff Person B stated
that rooms checks are completed every 15 minutes, however, some room checks are
completed more frequently depending on the resident’s treatment plan. She stated that
she uses a flashlight when looking inside the residents’ rooms. She reported that during
room checks, she looks for the resident being physically in the bed, breathing and she
has to see some part of the resident’s body before she leaves the room.
I interviewed Children's Village Staff Person C face-to-face at the facility on January 21,
2020. Staff Person C reported that she worked on January 7, 2020 from 3:00 p.m. to
11:00 p.m. She stated that she was sitting in the hallway from 8:00 p.m.-8:30 p.m. until
10:00 p.m. when she went to the top of the hallway to complete paperwork. Staff
Person C reported that when the residents were getting ready for bed residents were
constantly talking to staff and asking for different items. She reported that the residents
she was assigned to monitor were all in their beds. Staff Person C stated that she did
not see Resident 1 and Resident 2 go into Resident 3’s room. She reported that when
she completes room checks, she peeks in the room to look at the residents. She
reported that she looks for sign of life e.g. breathing or watching for the blanket to move.
She also stated that she has to see some part of the resident’s body. Staff Person C
reported that she only flashes a light on a resident when they are on suicidal watch.
She reported that she completes a form when room checks are finished.
4

On January 21, 2020, I reviewed video footage regarding the incident. Children’s Village
Administrator reported that the residents are assigned to certain staff for monitoring
during the day until bedtime. Staff Person A was assigned to Resident 2. Staff Person
C was assigned to Resident 1 and Resident 3. She stated that the residents are allowed
to close the doors at night if it has been deemed safe, however, staff are required to see
skin when they complete their room checks. The video footage began at 9:49 p.m. and
staff were by the office. Resident 1 entered Resident 3’s room at 9:51 p.m. Staff is
observed to complete a room check at 10:00 p.m. At 10:04 p.m., Resident 2 entered
Resident 3’s room. Staff completed room checks every 15 minutes by looking into the
door windows and opening the doors. At 12:07 a.m., Staff Person D is seated in the
hallway and Resident 1 left out of Resident 3’ room with a garment covering her body
and walked down the hallway. At 12:08 a.m., Staff Person D went to Resident 1’s room
and turned on the light. Staff Person D then walked out of the camera’s view towards
the bathroom. At 12:09 a.m., Staff Person E looked into Resident 1’s room. At 12:12
a.m., Staff Person E went to Resident 3’s room and opened the door. At 12:17 a.m.,
Resident 1 entered her room. Staff Person D completed room checks from 12:26 a.m.
until 7:00 a.m. At 7:02 a.m., Children’s Village Staff Person F turned on the lights and
began to check rooms. Resident 3 left her room at 7:03 a.m. Resident 2 left Resident
3’s room at 7:05 a.m.
On January 21, 2020, I reviewed room check logs for the night of the incident. It was
documented that room checks were completed every 15 minutes beginning at 9:30 p.m.
until 7:00 a.m.
I interviewed Children’s Village Staff Person D face-to-face at the facility on January 29,
2020. She stated that she arrived for her shift at 11:00 p.m. She stated that she
completed her first room check and everything looked normal. Staff Person D stated
that when she completes room checks, she uses a flashlight and opens the resident’s
door. She reported that she has to see a part of the resident’s body e.g. a foot or face
and she looks for shoes. Staff Person D stated that she does not enter the room. She
reported that approximately at 11:15 p.m., she heard white noise, which she uses to
help her fall asleep, coming from Resident 3’s room. She stated that she went to the
room and Resident 3 asked if she could close her door because she wanted to turn the
white noise up. Staff Person D stated that she told her that she could not close the
door, but she could leave the door cracked open. She reported that she heard Resident
3 say something, so she opened the door and asked her who she was talking to.
Resident 3 said that she was talking to herself. Staff Person D reported that she then
walked back down the hallway and told her supervisor what occurred. She reported
that Children’s Village Staff Person E then went to Resident 3’s room and talked to her
while Staff Person E stood in the hallway. She stated that at midnight, she completed a
room check and sat back down at the desk that was in the middle of the hallway. She
reported that once she sat down Resident 1 came out of Resident 3’s room. She
reported that at first, she did not know it was Resident 1 because she had a blanket
wrapped around her covering her face. However, she knew it could not be Resident 3
walking towards the bathroom because Resident 3 was taller than Resident 1. Staff
Person D stated that she called out Resident 1’s name but she continued to walk
5

towards the bathroom. She reported that she then went to Resident 1’s room, turned on
the light and saw a braid hanging down from the pillow. Staff Person D reported that
she then went to Resident 3’s room and Resident 3 was in bed with her eyes closed.
She reported that she then went to the bathroom and asked Resident 1 how long she
had been in Resident 3’s room. Resident 1 said she did not know. Staff Person D
indicated that she continued to complete 15-minute room checks until she went to
another building for staff rotation at 1:30 a.m. She stated that she returned to Mandy’s
Place around 4:30 a.m. and continued to complete her room checks until the morning
staff arrived at 6:45 a.m. Staff Person D reported that when she completed her room
checks everyone appeared to be in their correct rooms and she did not notice anything
odd. She stated that she was informed about Resident 2 being in Resident 3’s room
after she had already left the facility.
I interviewed Children's Village Staff Person E face-to-face at the facility on January 29,
2020. Staff Person E stated that she arrived at the facility a little before 11:00 p.m. She
reported that the afternoon staff told her that Resident 3 was leaving the next day and it
was her birthday. She then went to Resident 3’s room to say goodbye and wish her
well. She reported that she then went back to the lobby. Staff Person E reported that
approximately 25 minutes later Staff Person D told her that Resident 1 walked out of
Resident 3’s room and went to the bathroom. She stated that she went to the bathroom
and questioned Resident 1 about being in Resident 3’s room. She reported that she
then went to Resident 1’s room and saw that she made a dummy to look like a body.
Staff Person E then went to Resident 3’s room and asked her how long Resident 1 was
in her room. Resident 3 told her that Resident 1 was in her room since about 10:00
p.m. Staff Person E stated that she left the facility at 7:00 a.m. and was then informed
about Resident 2 being in Resident 3’s room too.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to show that Children’s Village
staff did not complete room checks at least every 15 minutes.
The room check log documented that room checks were
completed on January 7, 2020 every 15 minutes from 9:30 p.m.
to 7:00 a.m.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: There is sufficient evidence to show that Children’s Village staff
did not follow their nightly supervision policy. The policy states
that when completing room checks, staff must complete a visual
inspection which includes seeing skin, arms, legs or head
protruding from under the blanket. The visual inspections were
not completed per Children’s Village’s policy as Resident 1 was
in Resident 3’s room from 9:51 p.m. to 12:07 a.m. and Resident
2 was in Resident 3’s room from 10:04 p.m. until 7:05 a.m.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that the facility’s
regular license status continue.
